items.synopsis: With a review calling for major change at Australia's central bank, was an internal promotion the best choice for governor? We asked three experts.

title.children: Is Michele Bullock the right choice as RBA governor? The experts are divided

image.altText: An ambulance driving past the Royal Adelaide Hospital

items.synopsis: A man has died and a young woman remains in hospital following suspected overdoses involving a synthetic opioid called protonitazene. The latest cases follow two confirmed overdoses last week.

title.children: Health authorities issue warning over synthetic opioid after suspected death

image.altText: The exterior of the Supreme Court of South Australia.

items.synopsis: A man charged with attempted murder after shooting his cousin amid a dispute about a gold watch is found not guilty by an SA Supreme Court judge, who ruled that "the defendant was mentally incompetent to commit the offence".

title.children: Man who shot cousin over gold watch 'did not know his conduct was wrong', judge rules

image.altText: Michele Bullock fronting a Senate estimates hearing

items.synopsis: Michele Bullock will become the first woman to lead the Reserve Bank of Australia, replacing incumbent Philip Lowe following months of speculation about the governor's future.

title.children: Michele Bullock becomes first woman to serve as RBA governor, replacing Philip Lowe

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a dark suit holds a press conference in front of a lectern. Aboriginal and Australian flags are behind him.

items.synopsis: The pesticides authority CEO and board chair resign, after a review triggered by allegations one of the agency's workers urinated on his colleagues.

title.children: Following claims a public servant urinated on colleagues, pesticides authority CEO and board chair resign

image.altText: A number plate wedged in a tree.

items.synopsis: The crash was one of several recent incidents on SA roads, with a Queensland pair arrested after a stolen car with a space saver tyre was detected at 170kph, and a teenage pedestrian taken to hospital after a car allegedly mounted a kerb.

title.children: Number plate wedged between branches as flaming Audi brings down tree in suburban Adelaide

image.altText: Smiling person, short brown hair, hands on hip, wears Australian Army uniform dress. Sunshine, blurred house, greenery behind.

items.synopsis: When Captain Jesse Noble realised they were gender diverse, it felt like being " hit in the face with a truck". A Christian marriage, their faith, and their career in the army were all at stake.

title.children: How Jesse's dress is overturning the army's gender diversity policy

image.altText: Headstones inside a cemetery, sunny day.

items.synopsis: A South Australian man's body could lie in a funeral home for three months before he is given a dignified burial. His is one of 25 bodies in the state that has no next of kin.

title.children: South Australia's loneliest deaths when there is no next of kin to claim the body

image.altText: A woman standing out the front of her home smiling at the camera

items.synopsis: Switching from gas heating to reverse-cycle air conditioning could save households hundreds on their annual power bills, a report finds.

title.children: 'Won't have to wear the gloves': Family embraces switch from gas heater to reverse-cycle

image.altText: A blue lake, with a green cliff and a rural city stretching on behind the cliff.

items.synopsis: Investigations are under way into a foul smell that has hung over the South Australian city of Mount Gambier, prompting complaints and speculation by locals online.

title.children: Something smells in Mount Gambier and the EPA has been called in to find out what

image.altText: A father holds a baby, as he stands at a window.

items.synopsis: Australian men are reporting high-level loneliness. These experts are trying to understand why, and what can be done to fix the problem.

title.children: Which age group of men are the loneliest? This survey had surprising results

image.altText: Deputy Ukrainian Defence Minister Hanna Maliar poses for a picture in front of army tanks.

items.synopsis: The weapons arrived a week after the United States said it would send them as part of an $US800 million security package.

title.children: Ukraine receives cluster munitions, pledges limited use as Russia threatens to use similar banned weaponry

image.altText: Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling

items.synopsis: The last time Hollywood's actors and writers went on strike at the same time, the biggest stars were fighting for residual pay cheques. Decades later, streaming giants and artificial intelligence are at the heart of the debate.

title.children: 'It's very disturbing to me': Why Hollywood CEOs are outraged actors and writers have walked off the job

image.altText: A graphic illustration of a brain floating in mid air, surrounded by vibrant hues of blue and purple.

items.synopsis: A cheap version of ketamine commonly used as a sedative might help some people with hard-to-treat depression, research finds, raising hopes that the off-label treatment could become less expensive.

title.children: 20 years ago scientists discovered by chance that ketamine could help depression. More questions are getting answered

image.altText: A hand caresses a platypus resting on a blanket.

items.synopsis: The death of a platypus found in a city suburb may reflect the fate of the entire species if we don't pay closer attention to how this Australian animal is faring.

title.children: Australia mourned the death of one platypus — how can we save the entire species?

image.altText: Energy drink

items.synopsis: The artificial sweetener aspartame has been listed as a possible carcinogenic hazard to humans.  But what does that mean for your diet soft drink habit? Here's how to digest the findings, writes Evangeline Mantzioris.

title.children: Should you stop drinking diet soft drinks after the new cancer advice?

image.altText: A surfer treading water near a surfboard with a sea otter on it.

items.synopsis: Sea otter 841 is a five-year-old female who has a history of aggression towards surfers. She'll probably end up in a zoo, but she may be euthanised.

title.children: Officials trying to capture 'very bold' sea otter that's been wrestling surfboards off surfers

image.altText: An older man leaves the ACT Magistrates Court

items.synopsis: Michael Rigo is arrested at his home, accused of sexually assaulting a teenage boy 40 years ago, when Mr Rigo was an Australian rules football umpiring coach.

title.children: Former Aussie rules umpiring coach faces court charged with persistent sexual abuse of 16-year-old boy

image.altText: A boy in a white shirt smiles as he looks over his shoulder at the camera

items.synopsis: A private college in Adelaide's north is fined $420,000 for breaching the Work Health and Safety Act after a teenage student drowned during a 2021 school camping trip.

title.children: Private college fined after teenager's death during school trip

image.altText: Peter Dutton rubs his eye.

items.synopsis: The Federal by-election for the seat of Fadden could deliver a blow or a boost for Peter Dutton next week, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: A huge hurdle is coming for Dutton — but a bigger challenge is right behind

image.altText: A young woman with grey hair and piercing blue-green eyes looks at her reflection in a handheld mirror

items.synopsis: Meet social media's "greyfluencers" — mostly young women who are encouraging others to embrace the beauty of their natural hair colour.

title.children: 'I haven't looked back': Meet the young women ditching hair dye and going grey

image.altText: A composite image of a woman wearing a blue saree next to a Barbie doll wearing a saree

items.synopsis: Sixty-four years ago, women all around the world couldn't see themselves as Barbie: a stick-thin doll with big-boobs, blonde hair and blue eyes. Three women share whether that's changed for them.

title.children: Barbie went from a stick-thin blonde to saris and nose rings. But has she changed enough?

image.altText: A Caucasian woman with brown hair, wearing glasses and a blazer.

items.synopsis: Incoming RBA governor Michele Bullock says she is aware of the "challenging" task she faces trying to tame inflation, after being appointed to succeed Philip Lowe. Follow live.

title.children: Incoming RBA boss says she is coming into role at 'challenging time' for economy

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Michele Bullock has spent much of her career at the central bank, but after a review of the RBA called for major change, was the internal promotion the right call for the next governor? After a brief appearance here on the blog, my colleague Michael Janda spoke to three experts to find out what they make of the decision, and what it could mean for the future of the RBA and the economy. You can read their thoughts below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is Michele Bullock the right choice as RBA governor? Experts are divided

featuredLink.title: Is Michele Bullock the right choice as RBA governor? The experts are divided

children.content: Michele Bullock has spent much of her career at the central bank, but after a review of the RBA called for major change, was the internal promotion the right call for the next governor?
After a brief appearance here on the blog, my colleague
spoke to three experts to find out what they make of the decision, and what it could mean for the future of the RBA and the economy.
You can read their thoughts below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Shadow Treasurer Angus Taylor has welcomed Bullock's appointment, describing her as a "highly capable" economist who will lead the bank through the current economic climate. "Michele Bullock is a highly capable economist, with qualifications from the London School of Economics and University of New England, who has served the Reserve Bank with distinction for 38 years," he said in a statement. "With inflation at its highest level in three decades, it is essential Australians can have confidence in this crucial economic institution and that we continue to have a credible and capable Reserve Bank. "Families are feeling the impacts of higher prices and rising interest rates every day. Along with strong economic management, a strong Reserve Bank is essential to addressing the inflation that is driving higher prices." Taylor has also paid tribute to Philip Lowe, thanking him for his years of service. "[Mr] Lowe has been an independent, distinguished, and dedicated governor who has helped to steer Australia through some of our biggest economic challenges," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coalition welcomes appointment of 'highly capable' governor

children.content: has welcomed Bullock's appointment, describing her as a "highly capable" economist who will lead the bank through the current economic climate.

"Michele Bullock is a highly capable economist, with qualifications from the London School of Economics and University of New England, who has served the Reserve Bank with distinction for 38 years," he said in a statement.

"With inflation at its highest level in three decades, it is essential Australians can have confidence in this crucial economic institution and that we continue to have a credible and capable Reserve Bank.

"Families are feeling the impacts of higher prices and rising interest rates every day. Along with strong economic management, a strong Reserve Bank is essential to addressing the inflation that is driving higher prices."
Taylor has also paid tribute to Philip Lowe, thanking him for his years of service.
"[Mr] Lowe has been an independent, distinguished, and dedicated governor who has helped to steer Australia through some of our biggest economic challenges," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The secretary for the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Sally McManus, has welcomed the federal government's decision not to reappoint Philip Lowe as the Reserve Bank governor. She says while Lowe has served the country well, it provides an opportunity for a fresh look at how the central bank goes about its business. "There's been clearly mistakes made over the last couple of years and we're hoping that the new governor does take a new approach especially in the areas of wages and understanding how wages work as well as unemployment," she says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Unions welcome fresh appointment of new RBA governor

children.content: The secretary for the Australian Council of Trade Unions,
, has welcomed the federal government's decision not to reappoint Philip Lowe as the Reserve Bank governor.
She says while Lowe has served the country well, it provides an opportunity for a fresh look at how the central bank goes about its business.

"There's been clearly mistakes made over the last couple of years and we're hoping that the new governor does take a new approach especially in the areas of wages and understanding how wages work as well as unemployment," she says.
